contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means "telling Yahweh my deepest emotions." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: pouring out my soul before Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the idiom "As you live" shows that Hannah is being sincere and truthful. Alternate translation: "Sir, what I am going to tell you is certainly true" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Oh, my master! As you live, my master

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "be put to silence" are an idiom for "be made silent." This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "Yahweh will make them silent" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: the wicked will be put to silence

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means "defeated." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This is an idiom that means everywhere. Alternate translation: "the whole earth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This is an idiom that means "live in obedience to me." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "I will cause a man to become priest" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: I will raise up ... a faithful priest

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "to serve me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
Here "house" is an idiom used for "descendants." Alternate translation: "I will ensure that he always has a descendant who serves as high priest" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: I will build him a sure house

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "ears ... will tingle" is an idiom that means everyone will be shocked by what they hear. Alternate translation: "that will shock everyone who hears it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: at which the ears of everyone who hears it will tingle

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom to emphasize how serious Eli is. Alternate translation: "May God punish you the same way he said he will punish me, and even more" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: May God do so to you, and even more

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "be strong and fight" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This is an idiom which means he was very fearful or terribly concerned about something. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This is an idiom. "Yahweh severely judged" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "Yahweh punished" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
The words "by all means" are a forceful way of saying something. Alternate translation: "you must send a guilt offering" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: by all means send him a guilt offering

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means to be stubborn or unwilling to obey God. Alternate translation: "refuse to obey God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "looked up" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Here "with your whole heart" is an idiom that means to be completely devoted to something. Alternate translation: "become completely devoted to worshiping and obeying Yahweh only" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: return to Yahweh with your whole heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "confusion" here is used as a casual way of saying the Philistines were unable to think clearly. Alternate translation: "made them unable to think clearly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

The way a person lives is spoken of as walking on a path. Alternate translation: "do not do the things you do" or "do not do what is just the way you do" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: do not walk in your ways

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "rush upon" means that Yahweh's Spirit will influence Saul. In this case it means it means he will make Saul prophesy and act like a different person. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: The Spirit of Yahweh will rush upon you

contextId.occurrenceNote: God enabled Samuel to think differently from the way he had thought before. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

God touching a person's heart is an idiom that means God put something in their mind or moved them to do something. Alternate translation: "who wanted to go with Saul because God had changed their thinking" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

These expressions mean that people can actually see the kind of lives Saul and Samuel are living. Alternate translation: "the king's life was seen ... My life was seen" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: the king walking before you ... I have walked before you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom for "Samuel left and went up." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This is an idiom that means "we will teach you a lesson." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

This seems to be an idiom the means "Stop what you are doing." Saul did not want Ahijah to continue to use the ark to ask God for direction. Alternate translation: "Do not bring the sacred chest at this time" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This idiom means that he was strengthened. Alternate translation: "he regained his strength" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This idiom means that he was strengthened. Alternate translation: "I regained my strength" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

The idiom "the word of Yahweh came to" is used to introduce a special message from God. Alternate translation: "Yahweh gave a message to Samuel. He said," or "Yahweh spoke this message to Samuel:" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: the word of Yahweh came to Samuel, saying,

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means he had disobeyed the commandment. Alternate translation: "I have disobeyed what Yahweh commanded" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Here Yahweh is referred to as "the Strength of Israel" because he gives strength to the Israelites. Alternate translation: "Yahweh, who is the strength of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
This idiom appears to mean that Agag no longer thought he would be killed. Alternate translation: "Surely I am no longer in danger or dying" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Surely the bitterness of death has past

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "with him" means Yahweh helps and blesses David. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
Here "stand before me" is an idiom that means to continue in Saul's service. Alternate translation: "Let David stay in my service" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
Here "rose up against" is an idiom that refers to attacking. Alternate translation: "it attacked me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Here "the people" refers to the soldiers under David's command. The phrases "went out" and "came in" are idioms that refer to leading the people into battle and leading them home from battle. Alternate translation: "David led his soldiers into battle and led them home from battle" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: David went out and came in before the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "stood in awe" is an idiom that means to fear. Alternate translation: "he feared David" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: he stood in awe of him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrases "went out" and "came in" are idioms that refer to leading the people into battle and leading them home from battle. See how you translated this in [1 Samuel 18:13](../18/13.md). Alternate translation: "led his soldiers into battle and led them home from battle" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: went out and came in before them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "life in his hand" is an idiom that refers to risking his life. Alternate translation: "he risked his life" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: he took his life in his hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "save your life" is an idiom that refers to escape. Alternate translation: "If you do not escape" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: If you do not save your life

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "take my life" is an idiom for "kill me." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: that he seeks to take my life?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "far from it" is an idiom that refers to that it is not true. Alternate translation: "This is certainly not true" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
Here "step between me and death" is an idiom that refers to being very close to death. Alternate translation: "I am very close to death" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: there is but a step between me and death

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means it will never happen to you. Alternate translation: "This will never happen to you!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

This is an idiom. Jonathan uses this oath for emphasis and speaks of himself as if he were another person. Alternate translation: "may Yahweh do to me whatever harm my father intends to do to you, and even more than that" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-pronouns]])
contextId.glQuote: may Yahweh do to Jonathan and more also

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "business was in hand" is an idiom that refers to when everything happened. Alternate translation: "when everything happened" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: when the business was in hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Saul uses this phrase as a harsh rebuke to Jonathan and his concern for David. Alternate translation: "You stupid son of a prostitute" or "You stupid traitor" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: You son of a perverse, rebellious woman!

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "mother's nakedness" is an idiom that refers to the mother who gave birth to you. Alternate translation: "to the shame of your mother who gave birth to you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: to the shame of your mother's nakedness

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means "Absolutely not!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
Here "Turn" means to turn around or turn away from the king. Alternate translation: "Go and kill" or "Kill" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Here "Turn" means to turn around or turn away from the king. See how you translated this in [1 Samuel 22:17](../22/17.md). Alternate translation: "Go and kill the priests ... went and attacked" or "Kill the priest ... attacked the priests" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Turn and kill the priests ... turned and attacked the priests

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "try to kill him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This is an idiom. AT "encouraged him to trust in God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "even if I have to arrest every man in Judah" or "among all the clans of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: among all the thousands of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "arose" is an idiom for taking action. Alternate translation: "David took action; he quietly crept" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "David was sad because he had done something wrong" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
Here "bread" is an idiom for any kind of food. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
Here "house" is an idiom used for "descendants." Alternate translation: "Yahweh will ensure that my master always has a descendant who serves as king" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh will certainly make my master a sure house

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Abigail did not unload all gifts from the donkeys herself. Alternate translation: "accepted all the gifts that she had brought" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "has defended me after Nabal insulted me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: has taken up the cause of my insult from the hand of Nabal

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "arose" is an idiom for taking action. Alternate translation: "Then Saul took action and he went" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
attacking and taking property many times (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This is an idiom. "I could die because I listened" or "Someone could kill me because I listened" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: I have put my life in my hand and have listened

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. "As certainly as Yahweh lives" or "This is a true statement" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This is an idiom. "Saul's army began to lose the battle" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: The battle went heavily against Saul
